posts.cooked:
When sending a location I noticed that Google Maps was used for selecting locations.

Isn’t it true that Google tracks behaviour like searching/selecting locations?

Let’s suppose you want to secretly meet up with someone, Signal will provide the privacy for that. However, if you select it though Google Maps, Google knows you selected that location. Plus, if the other person clicks that same link, Google might figure out that you will be meeting with that person at that location.

Damn, this sounds really ´tin-foil-hatty’.

Besides, Signal using a service of the most privacy-invasive companies out there doesn’t sound like a good match.

I suggest using OSM for selecting locations.

There is some related discussion here:

Google starts charging for Maps API, effects for self-built Signal? Android Discussion
Here: https://mapsplatform.googleblog.com/2018/05/introducing-google-maps-platform.html , Google stated: Beginning June 11, you’ll need a valid API key and a Google Cloud Platform billing account to access our core products. I use my own Google API key to use in my own compiled Signal to make maps work, but I don’t have a billing account (I don’t even have a credit card, that’s way too expensive here and not needed for nearly all transactions). Would that mean my version will stop working afte…

link_counts.title: Google starts charging for Maps API, effects for self-built Signal?

I think it is very important to be independent from big companies like G00gle and still have the full functionality, which was already partly done with the direct apk download (btw there could be a link from the homepag…

posts.cooked:
hugopilot:

Damn, this sounds really ´tin-foil-hatty’ . …I suggest using OSM for selecting locations.

Personally what I would like to be able to do, is to transmit the “location” as a simple string with the GPS coordinates. This approach is not very useful for the use-case where you and your contact(s) are trying to coordinate a future meeting, at an arbitrary meeting-place.

  • person A is at location A (home/office/restaurant/whatever)
  • person B is at location B (somewhere else)
  • they want to see a movie at location C together

In that scenario, you really need a web-based mapping software thing, where you can find a location that you want “driving directions” from A to C, and you can transmit the destination to your friend, allowing them to easily also get turn-by-turn directions from B to C. There is pretty unavoidably going to be some metadata leakage here: you are both using network-based direction-services which need to know your location and your friend’s location and where you are going. Easy to put two-and-two together, and figure out that you are meeting each other. (Switching both of you to OSM just moves the goalposts… ideally, one of you would use mapquest, one of you would use gmaps, one of you would use OSM, and so on… plus IP-address-level anonymization to shield who was getting turn-by-turn directions to the movie theater at location C, exactly.)

But there is a different scenario, where you have a group of people that want to keep track of each other, but do not need to have turn-by-turn directions necessarily. Rather than organizing a group movie-watching-outing at distant location C, the scenario here is that you have half a dozen people that are all coordinating with each other at a political event, say. They are in a groupchat with each other. And they can crypto-call each other. But sometimes they will need to speak face-to-face, or to exchange physical paperwork, with each other. They also might just enjoy spending time together, and want to keep track of where their fellow groupchat members are (imagine a family on vacation at a ski resort rather than a political cabal at a political event if you prefer).

Every device in the groupchat is likely equipped with a location-sensing system; it might be passive GPS-satellite-reception based, it might be celltower-based, or it might be wifi-AP-based, or some combination thereof. Each person in the groupchat therefore knows their own location, in GPS coords at least, without needing any mapping-software or mapping-service, necessarily. And they ought to be able to transmit those bare GPS strings, to the other groupchat members, when the group has enable ‘share location with group’ or somesuch.

This would be done via signal protocol, and would just be bare strings, which means no special mapping-service-software is required on the recipient-devices. The members of the groupchat could of course use OSM/gmaps/mapquest/whatever, to display the location of all groupchat members on top of a streetmap or topomap layer, and get turn-by-turn directions from their location to the location of any other groupchat member. But if the group is concerned about metadata leakage to the network, the could also load up some public-domain mapping imagefiles (OSM tiles or USGS quads or whatnot stored locally) and overlay the bare GPS strings on that without needing any active network-connection.

The advantage here is that you get most of the benefits of mapping-software, but without actually needing any software for the mapping-effort. This would not work well in the have-everybody-meet-at-the-theater-downtown-from-their-locations-scattered-across-the-city-and-suburbs, but it DOES work well in the where-are-my-contacts-inside-this-convention-center-or-ski-resort kind of situation, methinks. So both kinds of approaches are needed, if we want signalapp to be useful in both kinds of scenarios. But I suspect that the “send my realtime location to another person” feature-request, will become MUCH more palatable if instead of sending it via google (or even via OSM webservers), I could simply tell my device to passively measure the current GPS location every 30 seconds or so, and automagically forward those bare GPS strings to my contact that I wanted to be aware of my ETA at our meeting-place.

They can do the same for me. And if we are careful, we can both see not just a mathematical estimate of as-the-crow-flies type of ETA, but a static map-layer beneath those bare GPS points which lets us visualize the environs and adjust our rough ETA estimates to something closer to reality. We need not reveal much to the watchful folks… it will just look like we are sending textual messages back and forth, with packet-sizes similar to the new isTyping feature. The badguys can see that we are communicating, in other words, but would not necessarily be aware that we were physically meeting (nor where the meeting took place).

So, I support making OSM an alternative mapping-service-provider, that would be a helpful step forwards. But my longterm dream is to be able to have physical meetings, and small-group-location-tracking, with ONLY the people in the group itself being privvy to the fact that meetings occurred and locations were swapped. Pure-client-side location feature, in other words, similar to the pure-client-side groupchat feature signalapp already offers.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Replacing Google maps with Open Street Map is one option, another option it to allow the user to set a preference. But in that case the message itself should provide neutral location information.

It would make sense to keep location information within the message neutral for privacy/security. I think the way it currently works, is that the sender interacts with Googlemaps to identify the street name and home number when he picks an address. If the receiver clicks on the link, Google will be able to tell that two people have referenced a very specific place within the same minute. Google can naturally assume that the tow people are in a chat together and that this location was shared.

Even if the lookup for the sender is preformed though a proxy, similar to how gifs are loaded, both sender and receiver see a link in their chat and both might click on it and thus still reveal that they are both talking about the same exact location at the same time. This location feature I think has a potential of leaking a little metadata, and over time a reasonable assumption can be made by Google of who shared locations with whom.

Especially in group chats. Even if the sender doesn’t click on the link, most recipients will. After a few location shares back and forth, most if not all members of the group can be linked together by Google.

posts.name: Jay Patel
posts.cooked: But Google is not foreign to signal anyhow i think providing Open source options is good thing.

posts.name: SignalUser
posts.cooked: But if you want to live someday without google you can start with small problemless things and remove it as maps.

Harold:

10 million users. If you leave freedom to choose all will opt for Google maps

Some will choose, but not ALL will opt for google maps. When i’m given a choice to choose, I choose to avoid any google related products. My goto map is OSM.
As long as we can choose between Google Maps or OSM, I’m all for it. I’d personally use Google Maps though.
news about the choice between OSM and GM?

actually I find it rather frustrating on iOS devices, that google maps is supported and apple maps is not.
iOS devices come with apple maps pre-installed and there are many people, who are just using apple maps and have google maps not even installed.
so even when I chat with someone on signal, as soon as I have to send my location, I have to switch to whatsapp. and that often ends with the question: then let’s just stay using whatsapp.

The choice of Google instead of OSM is one aspect. Why doesn’t it go further if I deny location permission? Why not allow me to select a point on the map and transmit the co-ordinates?

I enabled location and it doesn’t even work without Google Play services.

Could we also make it so that a offline map based app like OsmAnd is used(sending/receiving) instead of the OSM servers? OsmAnd easily shows lat-long coordinates of any point in the map and its easy to search with lat-long coordinates. I guess I’ll have to take these extra steps.

There are two sides to this: the privacy of the sender and the privacy of the receiver.

On the receiver side I think it would be best to use the Geo URI Scheme instead of a Link to maps.google.com. That way it will open in the default Maps-Application defined by your OS (my Android device offers to open such links with OsmAnd or Magic Earth for example). Here is an example link for you to try. At the moment Signal doesn’t even recognize such a link if I copy one into a message.

Protecting the Identity of the sender from the Service provider (in this case Google) is something that Signal thought about already in the case of Giphy:

The Signal service essentially acts as a VPN for GIPHY traffic: the Signal service knows who you are, but not what you’re searching for or selecting. The GIPHY API service sees the search term, but not who you are.

Implementing this for Google Maps too would be a big improvement imo.
